title: Jets' Jamal Adams wins appeal of fine for Baker Mayfield hit, celebrates win over NFL
text:
CLOSE Jets' S Jamal Adams celebrated Thursday after he won his appeal of a fine for his Week 2 hit on Baker Mayfield Andy Vasquez, Staff Writer, @andy_vasquez

FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets safety Jamal Adams was mad the moment the flag was thrown. He thought his Week 2 hit on Browns quarterback Baker Mayfield was clean.

A couple of days later, when the NFL fined him $21,056 for the roughing the passer penalty he was furious and ripped the league on social media as “a damn joke.”

But Thursday, Adams won his appeal of the fine, and giving him a rare reason for celebration in this frustrating Jets season.

“Ha ha! I told y’all, if you just listened to me,” Adams said Thursday, breaking into a celebratory dance as he spoke to reporters. “I’m going to be completely honest and I’m going to tell you, straight-up: I knew I was going to win it, because it was legal.”

Adams was penalized for a borderline hit on Mayfield: he hit the quarterback with his left arm and shoulder near the sideline as a running Mayfield threw a pass. Adams’ helmet cape close to hitting Mayfield’s, but replays weren’t definitive. Adams also appeared to turn his head out of the way just before contact.

When the flag was thrown, Adams immediately shook his head in disbelief and let the officials know he wasn’t pleased. And when he was fined, he let the whole world know how he felt, bashing the NFL on social media for its “soft rules protecting QBs” adding “I signed up to play football not two hand touch. Bull----!”

Aug 29, 2019; East Rutherford, NJ, USA; New York Jets strong safety Jamal Adams (33) reacts during warm ups before a game against the Philadelphia Eagles at MetLife Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Noah K. Murray-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Noah K. Murray-USA TODAY Sports)

After the rant, Adams said his mother was angry with him for using an expletive. Thursday was her birthday, and Adams said he planned to use the fine money to buy her a gift.

“Ha-ha! I got that, what was it, like 22 back in my pocket?” Adams said. “I’m just happy that it wasn’t taken out, because now I can spend that lovely money on my mother.”

Adams said that he understands why the league has rules and why players must play within them “to make it as safe as possible.” But he also made it clear that he’s not a fan of the direction the league is going with those rules, because it makes it difficult for a physical player like him.

“As a safety, obviously I don’t agree with a lot of things,” Adams said. “But it happens and we’ve got to adjust our level of play and how we play the game of football.”

But Adams said he won’t let the rules alter his hard-hitting style of play

“I’ve never been a dirty guy, but I am full-throttle when I’m on the field,” Adams said. “I’m never trying to take cheap shots at anybody, but at the same time I’m all about playing fast football. That’s never going to change for me.”

Adams, who made the Pro Bowl last season, seems to be striking the right balance. He hasn’t picked up a penalty since the Browns game and has only two unnecessary roughness penalties in 36 career games, according to NFLpenalties.com
description: Jets safety Jamal Adams had a rare reason to celebrate Thursday in what has been a frustrating season for the Jets.
